<!-- This article is about the ideology or movement known as gender-critical feminism or trans-exclusionary radical feminism, or any number of short forms of those names, including TERF, GC, and gender-critical --> {{Short description|Movement originating within radical feminism}} {{about|the movement originating within radical feminism|the related conservative movement|anti-gender movement}} {{Redirect|TERF|the acronym|TERF (acronym)}} {{pp-semi-indef|small=yes}} {{Use British English|date=December 2021}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2023}} [[File:TERF sticker.jpg|thumb|A sticker promoting gender-critical feminism]] '''Gender-critical feminism''', known to its opponents as '''trans-exclusionary radical feminism''', '''TERF ideology''' or '''TERFism''',<ref name="Thurlow" /><ref name="Williams" /><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rogers |first1=Baker A. |date=2023 |title=TERFs aren't feminists: lesbians stand against trans exclusion |journal=[[Journal of Lesbian Studies]] |pages=1–20 |doi=10.1080/10894160.2023.2252286 |pmid=37679960 |s2cid=261608725 |quote=many lesbians despise TERF ideology}}</ref><ref name=Bassi/> is an ideology or movement that opposes what it refers to as "[[gender ideology]]":<ref name=Pearce/> the concept of [[gender identity]] and [[transgender rights]], especially [[gender self-identification]]. Gender critical feminists believe that [[sex]] is biological and immutable,<ref>{{Cite web |last=UK Parliament |title=Employment Tribunal rulings on gender-critical beliefs in the workplace |url=https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/employment-tribunal-rulings-on-gender-critical-beliefs-in-the-workplace/ |access-date=22 October 2023 |website=House of Commons Library}}</ref> while believing gender, including both gender identity and [[gender roles]], is inherently oppressive.<ref name=":0">{{Citation |last1=Sullivan |first1=Alice |title=Introduction |date=10 July 2023 |url=https://www.taylorfrancis.com/books/9781003286608/chapters/10.4324/9781003286608-1 |work=Sex and Gender |pages=1–15 |access-date=20 October 2023 |edition=1 |place=London |publisher=Routledge |language=en |doi=10.4324/9781003286608-1 |isbn=978-1-003-28660-8 |last2=Todd |first2=Selina}}</ref> They reject the concept of [[transgender]] identities. These views have been described as [[transphobia|transphobic]] by [[Feminist views on transgender topics|feminist]] and scholarly critics,<ref name=Thurlow/><ref name="Bassi" /> and are opposed by many feminist and LGBT rights organizations.<ref name="Canada 110"/><ref name="Toutes des femmes"/>
While originally a [[fringe movement|fringe]] movement within feminism in the [[United States]],<ref name=Thomsen/><ref name=Bassi/> gender-critical views have achieved a degree of prominence in the [[United Kingdom]], where they have been at the centre of a number of high-profile controversies.<ref name=HinesSocRev/> The [[Council of Europe]] has condemned gender-critical ideology, among other ideologies, and linked it to "virulent attacks on the rights of LGBTI people" in Hungary, Poland, Russia, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and other countries.<ref name=Resolution2417/> and to the [[anti-gender movement]],<ref name="Council of Europe 2021"/> and in some countries, gender-critical groups have formed alliances with right-wing, [[far-right]], and [[anti-feminist]] organisations.<ref name="Butler idea of 'gender' backlash"/><ref name="CTV hate rise Canada"/><ref name="Alm & Engebretsen 2020"/><ref name=Studnik/>
== Terminology ==
=== Sex and gender ===
Gender-critical feminists equate "women" with what they consider to be a "female sex class", and view historical and contemporary oppression of women as being rooted in their being female, while "gender" is a system of social norms which functions to oppress women on the basis of their sex.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web |title=Woman as Resource: A Reply to Catharine MacKinnon - The Philosophers' Magazine |url=https://www.philosophersmag.com/essays/318-woman-as-resource-a-reply-to-catharine-mackinnon |access-date=21 October 2023 |website=www.philosophersmag.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kodsi |first1=Daniel |title=Who is feminism for? |date=3 July 2022 |url=https://thecritic.co.uk/who-is-feminism-for/ |access-date=14 August 2023}}</ref> They believe sex is biological and cannot be changed,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brione |first1=Patrick |title=Employment Tribunal rulings on gender-critical beliefs in the workplace |url=https://commonslibrary.parliament.uk/employment-tribunal-rulings-on-gender-critical-beliefs-in-the-workplace |access-date=14 August 2023}}</ref> and that biological sex should be a protected characteristic under equality legislation.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Elgot |first1=Jessica |title=Kemi Badenoch could rewrite law to allow trans exclusion from single-sex spaces |url=https://amp.theguardian.com/society/2023/apr/04/kemi-badenoch-could-rewrite-law-to-allow-trans-exclusion-from-single-sex-spaces |access-date=14 August 2023 |work=The Guardian |date=4 April 2023}}</ref> Furthermore, gender critics emphasise the view that sex is binary,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Cowan |first1=Sharon |last2=Morris |first2=Sean |title=Should 'Gender Critical' Views about Trans People Be Protected as Philosophical Beliefs in the Workplace? Lessons for the Future from Forstater, Mackereth and Higgs |journal=Industrial Law Journal |date=2022 |volume=51 |issue=1 |pages=1–37 |doi=10.1093/indlaw/dwac002 |url=https://academic.oup.com/ilj/article/51/1/1/6536993|doi-access=free }}</ref> as opposed to a continuous spectrum, and that the two sexes have an objective, material basis as opposed to being socially constructed.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Stock |first1=Kathleen |title=Material Girls: Why Reality Matters for Feminism |date=2021 |publisher=Fleet |isbn=9780349726595 |pages=44–75 |chapter=Chapter 2: What is sex?}}</ref>
Gender-critical feminists promote the idea that sex is important.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Lawford-Smith |first1=Holly |title=Gender-Critical Feminism |date=2022 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=9780198863885}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Sex Matters to intervene in Equality Act case at Inner House |url=https://www.scottishlegal.com/articles/sex-matters-to-intervene-in-case-on-meaning-of-sex-in-equality-act |access-date=21 October 2023 |work=Scottish Legal News |date=3 October 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Searles |first1=Michael |title=Government to tell GMC 'women are women' and 'biological sex matters' |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2023/10/17/government-tell-gmc-women-are-women-biological-sex-matters/ |access-date=21 October 2023 |work=The Telegraph |date=17 October 2023}}</ref> In ''[[Material Girls: Why Reality Matters for Feminism|Material Girls]]'', [[Kathleen Stock]] discusses four areas in which she claims sex-associated differences are important, regardless of gender: [[Sex differences in medicine|medicine]], sport, [[sexual orientation]], and the social effects of heterosexuality (such as [[wage disparity]] and [[sexual assault]]).<ref>{{cite book |last1=Stock |first1=Kathleen |title=Material Girls: Why Reality Matters for Feminism |date=2021 |publisher=Fleet |isbn=9780349726595 |pages=76–108 |chapter=Chapter 3: Why does sex matter?}}</ref> [[Holly Lawford-Smith]] states: "Gender critical feminism is ''not'' 'about' trans. It is ''about'' sex."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lawford-Smith |first1=Holly |title=What Is Gender Critical Feminism (and why is everyone so mad about it)? |date=29 March 2021 |url=https://hollylawford-smith.org/what-is-gender-critical-feminism-and-why-is-everyone-so-mad-about-it/ |access-date=21 October 2023}}</ref>
In gender-critical discourse, the terms ''man'' and ''woman'' are used as sex-terms, assigned no more meaning than ''adult human male'' and ''adult human female'' respectively, in contrast to feminist theorists who argue these terms embody a social category distinct from matters of biology (usually referred to as ''gender''), with ''masculinity'' and ''femininity'' representing normative characteristics thereof.<ref>{{cite web |title=Feminist Perspectives on Sex and Gender |url=https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/feminism-gender/#SexDis |website=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy |access-date=15 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Byrne |first1=Alex |title=Are women adult human females? |journal=Philosophical Studies |date=January 2020 |volume=177 |issue=12 |page=22 |doi=10.1007/s11098-019-01408-8 |hdl=1721.1/128358 |s2cid=254943344 |url=https://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/128358/11098_2019_1408_ReferencePDF.pdf}}</ref> The phrase ''adult human female'' has become a [[slogan]] in gender-critical politics, and has been described as transphobic.<ref>{{cite news |title=Woman billboard removed after transphobia row |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-45650462 |access-date=15 August 2023 |work=BBC News |date=26 September 2018}}</ref>

|title=Introduction |journal=[[Transgender Studies Quarterly]] |date=1 May 2016 |volume=3 |issue=1–2 |pages=5–14 |doi=10.1215/23289252-3334127 |doi-access=free }}</ref> who espouse sentiments that == Views ==
=== Sex-based rights ===
Gender critical feminists advocate for what they call "sex-based rights," arguing that "women's human rights are based upon sex" and that "these rights are being eroded by the promotion of 'gender identity.'"<ref name=HinesSocRev>{{cite journal |last1=Hines |first1=Sally |title=Sex wars and (trans) gender panics: Identity and body politics in contemporary UK feminism |journal=[[The Sociological Review]] |date=2020 |volume=68 |issue=4 |pages=699–717 |doi=10.1177/0038026120934684 |s2cid=221097483 |url=https://eprints.whiterose.ac.uk/163972/8/0038026120934684.pdf |access-date=16 June 2023 |archive-date=14 December 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211214191345/https://eprints.whiterose.ac.uk/163972/8/0038026120934684.pdf |url-status=live }}</ref> The term is used, primarily in the UK, to refer to a variety of legal positions and political objectives, including:
* Existing exceptions defined in the UK [[Equality Act 2010]]. These exceptions do not grant any right for individuals to be offered single-sex services, but do allow service providers to offer such services, if they are “a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim”.<ref>{{cite web |title=Attorney General affirms sex-based rights |url=https://womansplaceuk.org/2022/08/11/attorney-general-affirms-sex-based-rights/ |website=Woman's Place UK |date=11 August 2022 |access-date=17 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Gender reassignment provisions in the Equality Act |url=https://www.equalityhumanrights.com/en/advice-and-guidance/gender-reassignment-provisions-equality-act |website=Equality and Human Rights Commission |access-date=11 September 2023}}</ref> * Proposed changes to the Equality Act to define sex as biological sex<ref>{{cite news |last1=Allegretti |first1=Aubrey |title=What would changing the Equality Act mean for trans people and single-sex spaces? |url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2023/apr/05/what-would-changing-the-equality-act-mean-for-trans-people-and-single-sex-spaces |access-date=17 August 2023 |work=The Guardian |date=5 April 2023}}</ref> * The belief that sex is central to the definition of women and women's rights, as opposed to basing law on gender identity.<ref name="scotsman">{{cite news |title=Women's rights declaration sparks accusations of discrimination|date=6 November 2019 |last=Davidson |first=Gina |url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/womens-rights-declaration-sparks-accusations-discrimination-2509098 |access-date=3 December 2021 |work=[[The Scotsman]] |archive-date=3 December 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211203153708/https://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/womens-rights-declaration-sparks-accusations-discrimination-2509098 |url-status=live }}</ref>
The gender-critical movement argues that recognition of transgender women as women conflicts with these rights.<ref name="trans_inclusive_criminology">|9={{cite journal | url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10612-021-09590-0 | doi=10.1007/s10612-021-09590-0 | title=Building an Intersectional and Trans-Inclusive Criminology: Responding to the Emergence of "Gender Critical" Perspectives in Feminist Criminology | year=2021 | last1=Valcore | first1=Jace | last2=Fradella | first2=Henry F. | last3=Guadalupe-Diaz | first3=Xavier | last4=Ball | first4=Matthew J. | last5=Dwyer | first5=Angela | last6=Dejong | first6=Christina | last7=Walker | first7=Allyn | last8=Wodda | first8=Aimee | last9=Worthen | first9=Meredith G. F. | journal=Critical Criminology | volume=29 | issue=4 | pages=687–706 | s2cid=244192331 | access-date=7 December 2021 | archive-date=7 December 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211207212229/https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10612-021-09590-0 | url-status=live }}</ref>
Human rights scholar Sandra Duffy described the concept of "sex-based rights" as "a fiction with the pretense of legality," noting that "[[international human rights law]] is not static or originalist."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Duffy |first1=Sandra |title=An International Human Rights Law Analysis of the WHRC Declaration |date=26 October 2021 |url=https://sandraduffy.wordpress.com/2021/10/26/an-international-human-rights-law-analysis-of-the-whrc-declaration/ |access-date=4 December 2021 |archive-date=16 June 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220616105029/https://sandraduffy.wordpress.com/2021/10/26/an-international-human-rights-law-analysis-of-the-whrc-declaration/ |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Catharine A. MacKinnon]] noted that "the recognition [that discrimination against trans people is discrimination on the basis of sex, that is gender, the social meaning of sex] does not, contrary to allegations of anti-trans self-identified feminists, endanger women or feminism, including what some in this group call 'women's sex-based rights.' To begin with, women—in the United States anyway—do not have 'sex-based rights' in the affirmative sense some in this group seem to think."<ref>{{cite journal |last1=MacKinnon |first1=Catharine A.|author-link= Catharine A. MacKinnon |title=A Feminist Defense of Transgender Sex Equality Rights |journal=[[Yale Journal of Law and Feminism]] |date=2023 |volume=34|url=https://openyls.law.yale.edu/bitstream/handle/20.500.13051/18252/88.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y}}</ref>
The gender-critical movement has also been critical of attempts to ban non-affirming transgender therapy, commonly referred to by its opponents as “conversion therapy”.<ref>{{cite web |last=Greenesmith |first=Heron |date=17 June 2020 |title=Gender Critical Support Board Promotes Therapists Who Reject Transgender Identities |url=https://www.teenvogue.com/story/gender-critical-support-board-trans-youth |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230822184401/https://www.teenvogue.com/story/gender-critical-support-board-trans-youth |archive-date=22 August 2023}}</ref>
=== Gender-segregated spaces === In 1996, [[Germaine Greer]] (at the time a [[Fellow#In ancient universities|fellow]] at [[Newnham College, Cambridge]]) unsuccessfully opposed the appointment to a fellowship of her transgender colleague [[Rachael Padman]].<ref name=garner>{{cite web|last=Garner|first=Clare|title=Fellows divided over don who breached last bastion|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/fellows-divided-over-don-who-breached-last-bastion-1257781.html|website=The Independent|access-date=7 March 2014|date=25 June 1997|archive-date=7 March 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307162149/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/fellows-divided-over-don-who-breached-last-bastion-1257781.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=featherstone>{{cite book|editor-last=Featherstone|editor-first=Mike|title=Body Modification|date=2000|publisher=Sage|location=London|isbn=9780761967958|pages=219–220|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EBs1PCbwF_0C|edition=1st publ.|access-date=25 April 2019|archive-date=18 February 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210218135458/https://books.google.com/books?id=EBs1PCbwF_0C|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Reynolds|first=Flo|title=Arts history: Germaine Greer|url=http://www.concrete-online.co.uk/germaine-greer/|website=Concrete|access-date=7 March 2014|date=19 February 2013|archive-date=7 March 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307215701/http://www.concrete-online.co.uk/germaine-greer/|url-status=live}}</ref> Greer argued that because Padman had been [[assigned male at birth]], she should not be admitted to Newnham, [[single-sex education|a women's college]]. Greer later resigned from Newnham.<ref>[http://www.pfc.org.uk/news/1997/gfolly02.htm In the news:1997] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060625052911/http://www.pfc.org.uk/news/1997/gfolly02.htm |date=25 June 2006 }} Press For Change.org.uk</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.salon.com:80/people/bc/1999/06/22/greer |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010601071715/http://www.salon.com/people/bc/1999/06/22/greer |url-status=dead |archive-date=1 June 2001 |title=Brilliant Careers – Germaine Greer |work=Salon.com |date=22 June 1999 |access-date=25 July 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Burwell |first1=Ian |title=Germaine Greer, profile: Writer who has not backed down from fight with transgender community |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/germaine-greer-profile-writer-who-has-not-backed-down-from-fight-with-transgender-community-a6742721.html |access-date=10 October 2018 |agency=The Independent |date=20 November 2015 |archive-date=11 October 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181011020746/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/germaine-greer-profile-writer-who-has-not-backed-down-from-fight-with-transgender-community-a6742721.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper = The Times|quote=Dr Greer: "Dr Padman's past was kept secret from us on the governing body. We were told by people outside the college making fun of Newnham and, frankly, we feel we have been made monkeys of."|date = 24 June 1997| title = Fellow who had sex change divides all-women college| last=Wilkins|first=Emma}}</ref>
A 2004 opinion piece by British radical feminist [[Julie Bindel]] titled "Gender Benders, beware" printed in ''[[The Guardian]]'' caused the paper to receive two hundred letters of complaint from transgender people, doctors, therapists, academics and others. The editorial expressed her anger at [[Kimberly Nixon]] and her views on transgender people.<ref name="GBB" /><ref>{{cite news |last1=Bindel |first1=Julie |title=My trans mission |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2007/aug/01/mytransmission |access-date=15 April 2019 |work=The Guardian |date=1 August 2007 |archive-date=12 April 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190412191101/https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2007/aug/01/mytransmission |url-status=live }}</ref> Transgender activist group [[Press for Change]] cite this article as an example of 'discriminatory writing' about transgender people in the press.<ref name="PFCGBB">{{cite web|title=Transsexual People and the Press: Collected Opinions from Transsexual People Themselves|url=http://pfc.org.uk/files/Transsexual_People_and_the_Press.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100927062232/http://pfc.org.uk/files/Transsexual_People_and_the_Press.pdf|archive-date=27 September 2010|last=Burns|first=Christine|date=23 November 2004|publisher=[[Press for Change]]|page=10|access-date=14 April 2019|url-status=dead}}</ref> Complaints focused on the title, "Gender benders, beware", the cartoon accompanying the piece,<ref name="PFCRESP">Claire McNab [https://www.webarchive.org.uk/wayback/archive/20061116120000/http://www.pfc.org.uk/pfclists/news%2Darc/2004q1/msg00061.htm Re: UK: Gender benders, beware]<!-- page not archived. see https://web.archive.org/web/20041011112700/http://www.pfc.org.uk:80/pfclists/news-arc/index.htm --> [The Guardian] McNab's reaction to PfC list on article</ref> and the disparaging tone, such as "Think about a world inhabited just by transsexuals. It would look like the set of ''[[Grease (musical)|Grease]]''" and "I don't have a problem with men disposing of their genitals, but it does not make them women, in the same way that shoving a bit of vacuum hose down your 501s [jeans] does not make you a man."<ref name="GBB">{{citation| last = Bindel| first = Julie| title = Gender Benders, beware| work = The Guardian| date = 31 January 2004| url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/jan/31/gender.weekend7| access-date = 16 June 2023| archive-date = 21 December 2016| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20161221142009/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/jan/31/gender.weekend7| url-status = live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Denham |first1=Jess |title=Death threats force feminist campaigner out of university debate |date=17 September 2013 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/student/news/death-threats-force-feminist-campaigner-out-of-university-debate-8821362.html |access-date=15 April 2019 |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |archive-date=15 April 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190415172941/https://www.independent.co.uk/student/news/death-threats-force-feminist-campaigner-out-of-university-debate-8821362.html |url-status=live }}</ref>
=== Socialisation and gender nonconformity ===
Radical feminists generally see gender as a system in which women are oppressed for reasons intrinsically related to their sex, and emphasize male violence against women, particularly involving institutions such as the [[sex industry]], as central to women's oppression.<ref name="McKay 2015">{{cite journal |last1=Mackay |first1=Finn |title=Radical Feminism |journal=Theory, Culture & Society |date=December 2015 |volume=32 |issue=7–8 |pages=332–336 |doi=10.1177/0263276415616682 |s2cid=220719287 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Bettcher |first1=Talia Mae |editor1-last=Disch |editor1-first=Lisa |editor2-last=Hawkesworth |editor2-first=Mary |title=The Oxford Handbook of Feminist Theory |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford |isbn=9780199328581 |pages=407–427 |chapter=Intersexuality, transgender and transsexuality|year=2016 }}</ref>
===Intersex women=== Radical feminist [[Germaine Greer]] called women with XY [[Androgen insensitivity syndrome|AIS]] "men" and "incomplete males" in her 1999 book ''The Whole Woman''. [[Iain Morland]] responded that "in trying to criticize the social construction of femaleness and intersex, Greer disenfranchised precisely those people who live at the intersection of the two categories."<ref>{{cite web|title=''Progress and Politics in the intersex rights movement, Feminist theory in action''|url=http://www.aisia.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Dreger__Herndon_2009.pdf|author1=Alice D. Dreger |author2=April M. Herndon }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/232519105|title=Intersex Activism, Feminism and Psychology: Opening a Dialogue on Theory, Research and Clinical Practice | Request PDF}}</ref>
Most intersex organizations subscribe to a mixed [[Social construction of gender|sociological perspective of sex and gender]], and as trans legislation and subjects overlaps heavily with intersex legislation, intersex people are often involved in [[trans activism]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://interactadvocates.org/transgender-legislation-intersex/|title=Understanding How Anti-Transgender Legislation Also Affects Intersex Kids}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.taylorfrancis.com/chapters/edit/10.4324/9781003206255-60/hermaphrodites-attitude-cheryl-chase|title=The Transgender Studies Reader Remix|first=Cheryl|last=Chase|chapter=Hermaphrodites with Attitude: Mapping the Emergence of Intersex Political Activism |date=14 July 2022|publisher=Routledge|doi=10.4324/9781003206255-60|isbn=9781003206255 }}</ref> Intersex women who display a mixed sexual [[phenotype]] often face [[Violence against transgender people|attacks similar to trans people]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/health/most-state-bans-on-gender-affirming-care-for-trans-youth-still-allow-controversial-intersex-surgery|title=Most state bans on gender-affirming care for trans youth still allow controversial intersex surgery|date=23 March 2023|website=PBS NewsHour}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2022/10/26/us-anti-trans-bills-also-harm-intersex-children|title=US: Anti-Trans Bills Also Harm Intersex Children|date=26 October 2022}}</ref>
== History ==
=== Early history (before 1990) === Although trans people were active in feminist movements in the 1960s and earlier,<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10714420802306726 | doi=10.1080/10714420802306726 | title=Stray Thoughts on Transgender Feminism and the Barnard Conference on Women | year=2008 | last1=Stryker | first1=Susan | journal=The Communication Review | volume=11 | issue=3 | pages=217–218 | s2cid=145011138 | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=2 December 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211202214504/https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10714420802306726 | url-status=live }}</ref> the 1970s saw conflict among some early [[radical feminists]] over the inclusion of trans women in feminism.<ref>{{Citation|last=Bettcher|first=Talia|title=Feminist Perspectives on Trans Issues|date=2014|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/spr2014/entries/feminism-trans/|encyclopedia=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Spring 2014|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=13 April 2019|archive-date=28 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190328062920/https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/spr2014/entries/feminism-trans/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/08/04/woman-2|title=What Is a Woman? The dispute between radical feminism and transgenderism|last=Goldberg|first=Michelle|date=5 August 2014|work=New Yorker Magazine|access-date=1 December 2019|archive-date=13 November 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191113031943/https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/08/04/woman-2|url-status=live}}</ref>
[[Janice Raymond]]'s ''[[The Transsexual Empire]]'', published in 1979, purported to examine the role of transgender identity in reinforcing traditional gender stereotypes, in particular the ways in which the "medical-psychiatric complex" was medicalizing gender identity, and the social and political context that contributed to the image of gender-affirming treatment and surgery as therapeutic medicine.<ref name="Raymond 1994">{{cite book | title=The Transsexual Empire: The Making of the She-male | last=Raymond | first=Janice G. | publisher=Teachers College Press | location=New York | isbn=978-0807762721 | year=1994 | edition=2nd | url=https://janiceraymond.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/The%20Transsexual%20Empire.pdf | access-date=24 May 2019 | archive-date=8 November 2019 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191108205024/http://janiceraymond.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/The%20Transsexual%20Empire.pdf | url-status=live }}</ref> Raymond maintained that this was based in the "patriarchal myths" of "male mothering", and "making of woman according to man's image", and that transgender identity aimed "to colonize feminist identification, culture, politics and sexuality."<ref name="Raymond 1994"/> The book goes on to say that “All transsexuals [[rape]] women's bodies by reducing the real female form to an artifact” and that “the problem of transsexualism would best be served by morally mandating it out of existence“. <ref>Raymond, Janice. (1994). ''The Transsexual Empire'', p. 104, 178</ref> Several authors have since characterized this work as transphobic and constituting hate speech, as well as lacking any serious intellectual basis.<ref name="Rose 2004">{{cite journal|last=Rose|first=Katrina C.|year=2004|url=http://www.ifge.org/?q=node/237|title=The Man Who Would be Janice Raymond|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190329234214/http://www.ifge.org/?q=node%2F237 |archive-date=29 March 2019|journal=Transgender Tapestry|volume=104}}</ref><ref name="Serano 2007">{{cite book|first=Julia|last=Serano|author-link=Julia Serano|year=2007|title=Whipping Girl: A Transsexual Woman on Sexism and the Scapegoating of Femininity|pages=233–234|publisher=Da Capo Press |isbn=9781580051545}}</ref><ref name="Namaste 2000">{{cite book|last=Namaste|first=Viviane K.|author-link=Viviane Namaste|year=2000|title=Invisible Lives: The Erasure of Transsexual and Transgendered People|pages=33–34|publisher=University of Chicago Press |isbn=9780226568102}}</ref><ref name="Hayes 2003">{{cite journal|last=Hayes|first=Cressida J.|author-link=Cressida Heyes|year=2003|title=Feminist Solidarity after Queer Theory: The Case of Transgender|journal=Signs|volume=28|number=4|pages=1093–1120|doi=10.1086/343132|jstor=10.1086/343132|s2cid=144107471}}</ref>
In her own 1987 book ''[[Gyn/Ecology]]'', [[Mary Daly]], who had served as Raymond's thesis supervisor,<ref>{{Cite web|title=Feminist theologian Mary Daly dies|url=https://www.ebar.com/news///240420|access-date=3 July 2020|website=The Bay Area Reporter / B.A.R. Inc.|language=en|archive-date=8 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210308171932/https://www.ebar.com/news///240420|url-status=live}}</ref> argued that as sex reassignment surgery cannot reproduce female chromosomes or a female life history, it could "not produce women".<ref>Daly, Mary, ''Gyn/Ecology: The Metaethics of Radical Feminism'' (Boston, Mass.: Beacon Press, pbk. [1st printing? printing of [19]90?] 1978 & 1990 (prob. all content except ''New Intergalactic Introduction'' 1978 & prob. ''New Intergalactic Introduction'' 1990) ({{ISBN|0-8070-1413-3}})).</ref> [[Sheila Jeffreys]] and [[Germaine Greer]] have made similar remarks.<ref name = BINDEL2>{{cite news | last= Bindel | first= Julie | author-link= Julie Bindel | title= The ugly side of beauty | work= [[The Guardian]] | date= 2 July 2005 | url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/jul/02/gender.politicsphilosophyandsociety | access-date= 16 June 2023 | archive-date= 25 February 2021 | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20210225140358/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/jul/02/gender.politicsphilosophyandsociety | url-status= live }}</ref> In a response to related remarks by [[Elizabeth Grosz]], philosopher [[Eva Simone Hayward|Eva Hayward]] characterized this type of view as telling trans people who have had sex reassignment surgery: "Don't exist."<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hayward |first1=Eva S. |title=Don't Exist |journal=[[Transgender Studies Quarterly]] |date=2017 |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=191–194|doi=10.1215/23289252-3814985 }}</ref>
== Around the world ==
=== United Kingdom === <!-- More detail and more sources about the early history would be nice -->
In 2016, the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]]' [[Women and Equalities Committee]] issued a report recommending that the [[Gender Recognition Act 2004]] be updated "in line with the principles of [[gender self-declaration]]".<ref>{{cite report|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201516/cmselect/cmwomeq/390/39010.htm#_idTextAnchor213|title=Transgender Equality|last1=Women and Equalities Committee|date=8 January 2016|publisher=House of Commons|quote=Within the current Parliament, the Government must bring forward proposals to update the Gender Recognition Act, in line with the principles of gender self-declaration that have been developed in other jurisdictions. In place of the present medicalised, quasi-judicial application process, an administrative process must be developed, centred on the wishes of the individual applicant, rather than on intensive analysis by doctors and lawyers.|access-date=1 November 2021}}</ref> Later in 2016, in [[England and Wales]], a proposal was developed under [[Theresa May]]'s government to revise the Act to introduce self-identification, with a public consultation opening in 2018. This proposed reform became a key locus of conflict for the emerging gender-critical movement, seeking to block reform of the Act, with a number of groups such as [[Fair Play For Women]], [[For Women Scotland]], and [[Woman's Place UK]] being formed. 2018 found a significant majority of respondents in favour of the GRA reforms,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/response-to-the-gender-recognition-act-2004-consultation |title=Reform of the Gender Recognition Act — Analysis of consultation responses |first1=Daniel |last1=King |author2=Carrie Paechter |author3=Maranda Ridgway |publisher=[[Her Majesty's Stationery Office]] |date=22 September 2020 |access-date=21 October 2021 |id=CP 294 |pages=8–9 |archive-date=5 October 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201005045042/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/response-to-the-gender-recognition-act-2004-consultation |url-status=live }}</ref> however, in 2020, [[Second Johnson ministry|Boris Johnson's government]] dropped the reforms, instead reducing the cost of a gender recognition certificate and moving the application process online.
Another key locus of conflict for the emerging movement was the stance of LGBT rights charity [[Stonewall (charity)|Stonewall]] on trans issues. In 2015, Stonewall had begun campaigning for trans equality, with Stonewall head [[Ruth Hunt]] apologising for the organisation's previous failure to do so.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gani|first1=Aisha|title=Stonewall to start campaigning for trans equality|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/feb/16/stonewall-start-campaigning-trans-equality|access-date=31 May 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=16 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426042549/http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/feb/16/stonewall-start-campaigning-trans-equality|archive-date=26 April 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> In 2019, the [[LGB Alliance]] was founded in opposition to Stonewall, accusing the organization of having "undermined women's sex-based rights and protections" and attempting "to introduce confusion between biological sex and the notion of gender."<ref>{{Cite news |last=Hellen |first=Nicholas |date=22 September 2019 |title='Anti-women' trans policy may split Stonewall |work=The Sunday Times |location=London |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/anti-women-trans-policy-may-split-stonewall-wfv2rp5cx |access-date=13 February 2021 |archive-date=1 February 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210201130445/https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/anti-women-trans-policy-may-split-stonewall-wfv2rp5cx |url-status=live }}</ref>
2019 saw the formation of the [[Women's Human Rights Campaign]] (now Women's Declaration International) by noted gender-critical feminist [[Sheila Jeffreys]] and co-founder Heather Brunskell-Evans. The group published a manifesto titled the ''Declaration on Women's Sex-Based Rights'', which argued that recognising trans women as women "constitutes discrimination against women" and called for the "elimination of that act."<ref>{{cite news |title=MPs urged by anti-trans 'women's rights' group to eliminate 'transgenderism' and scrap Gender Recognition Act |url=https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2021/01/27/womens-human-rights-campaign-gender-recognition-act-inquiry-trans-transphobia/ |access-date=2 December 2021 |work=[[Pink News]] |archive-date=22 September 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220922041648/https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2021/01/27/womens-human-rights-campaign-gender-recognition-act-inquiry-trans-transphobia/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.womensdeclaration.com/en/declaration-womens-sex-based-rights-full-text/ | title=Declaration on Women's Sex-Based Rights: Full Text - Women's Declaration International | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=7 December 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211207043837/https://womensdeclaration.com/en/declaration-womens-sex-based-rights-full-text/ | url-status=live }}</ref>
2019 also saw the preliminary hearings of ''[[Maya Forstater v Centre for Global Development]]'', in which tax expert and researcher Maya Forstater made a claim that she had been discriminated against by her employer for her gender-critical beliefs. In June 2021 Maya Forstater, who lost her job with the Centre for Global Development, won an appeal against the original employment tribunal decision.<ref>Maya Forstater v CGD Europe UKEAT/0105/20/JOJ</ref> The Employment Appeal Tribunal (EAT) found that gender-critical beliefs, such as the view that sex is fixed and should not be conflated with gender identity, did qualify for protection under the [[Equality Act 2010]] (Equality Act). This means that "gender critical" beliefs are protected "philosophical beliefs" for equality law purposes. In June 2023 Forstater was awarded more than £100,000 in compensation by an employment tribunal.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Bryant |first=Miranda |date=1 July 2023 |title=Woman who lost job after tweeting view on biological sex awarded £100,000 |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2023/jul/01/maya-forstater-woman-who-lost-job-after-tweeting-view-on-biological-sex-awarded-100000-by-tribunal |access-date=13 July 2023 |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
A 2020 paper in [[SAGE Open]] said that "the case against trans inclusion in the United Kingdom has been presented primarily through social media and blog-type or journalistic online platforms lacking the traditional prepublication checks of academic peer review".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zanghellini |first1=Aleardo |title=Philosophical Problems With the Gender-Critical Feminist Argument Against Trans Inclusion |journal=SAGE Open |date=1 April 2020 |volume=10 |issue=2 |pages=2158244020927029 |doi=10.1177/2158244020927029 |s2cid=219733494 |doi-access=free }}</ref> Some public figures such as [[Graham Linehan]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2021/11/12/gender-critical-coming-out-day-trans-graham-linehan-mumsnet/ | title=A so-called 'gender critical coming out day' for TERFs sparks blistering backlash | date=12 November 2021 | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=8 December 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208221551/https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2021/11/12/gender-critical-coming-out-day-trans-graham-linehan-mumsnet/ | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://gcn.ie/graham-linehan-trans-conversion-therapy/ | title=Graham Linehan calls for list of Irish 'gender critical' therapists for trans children | date=5 February 2020 | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=5 March 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220305195408/https://gcn.ie/graham-linehan-trans-conversion-therapy/ | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/27/entertainment/graham-linehan-twitter-removal-trnd/index.html | title=Graham Linehan, creator of 'The IT Crowd' and 'Father Ted,' has been removed from Twitter | date=27 June 2020 | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=8 December 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208221549/https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/27/entertainment/graham-linehan-twitter-removal-trnd/index.html | url-status=live }}</ref> and [[J.K. Rowling]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/10/entertainment/jk-rowling/index.html | title=J.K. Rowling explains her gender identity views in essay amid backlash | website=[[CNN]] | date=10 June 2020 | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=24 November 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211124202606/https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/10/entertainment/jk-rowling/index.html | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2020/jun/11/why-is-jk-rowling-speaking-out-now-on-sex-and-gender-debate | title=Why is JK Rowling speaking out now on sex and gender debate? | newspaper=The Guardian | date=11 June 2020 | last1=Brooks | first1=Libby | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=9 December 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211209194802/https://www.theguardian.com/books/2020/jun/11/why-is-jk-rowling-speaking-out-now-on-sex-and-gender-debate | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/opinion/columnists/why-feminists-like-me-stand-with-jk-rowling-in-trans-rights-row-susan-dalgety-2910085|title=Why feminists like me stand with JK Rowling in trans rights row – Susan Dalgety | The Scotsman|access-date=8 December 2021|archive-date=8 December 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208221551/https://www.scotsman.com/news/opinion/columnists/why-feminists-like-me-stand-with-jk-rowling-in-trans-rights-row-susan-dalgety-2910085|url-status=live}}</ref> have often been featured in social media gender-critical rhetoric.{{Clarify|date=August 2023}} The internet forum [[Mumsnet]] has also been a prominent hub of online gender-critical discourse.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/jun/13/mumsnet-transgender-row-feminism-tougher-forum-rules | title=Mumsnet brings in tougher forum rules after transgender row | newspaper=The Guardian | date=13 June 2018 | last1=Ntim | first1=Zac | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=8 December 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208221550/https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/jun/13/mumsnet-transgender-row-feminism-tougher-forum-rules | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/mumsnet-moderators-trans-rights-debate | title=Mumsnet moderators are struggling to find the line between free speech and transphobia | magazine=Wired UK }}</ref>
Gender-critical views are common in the British media.<ref name="Burns 2019"/><ref name="cnn_uk_media">{{cite web | url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/10/09/uk/uk-trans-rights-gender-critical-media-intl-gbr-cmd/index.html | title=Anti-trans rhetoric is rife in the British media. Little is being done to extinguish the flames | website=[[CNN]] | date=9 October 2021 | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=11 March 2023 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230311180308/https://www.cnn.com/2021/10/09/uk/uk-trans-rights-gender-critical-media-intl-gbr-cmd/index.html | url-status=live }}</ref> The British press frequently publishes articles critical of trans people and trans issues.<ref name="cnn_uk_media" /> In 2018, the US version of ''The Guardian'' published an editorial condemning an editorial in the UK version of ''The Guardian'' for transphobia, because it portrayed trans rights as opposed to the rights of cis women.<ref name="us_guardian_response">{{cite news|last1=Levin|first1=Sam|last2=Chalabi|first2=Mona|last3=Siddiqui|first3=Sabrina|date=2 November 2018|title=Why we take issue with the Guardian's stance on trans rights in the UK|language=en-GB|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/nov/02/guardian-editorial-response-transgender-rights-uk|access-date=14 May 2019|issn=0261-3077|archive-date=23 May 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190523043608/https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/nov/02/guardian-editorial-response-transgender-rights-uk|url-status=live}}</ref> Drawing on theory of [[radicalization]], Craig McLean argues that discourse on transgender-related issues in the UK has been radicalized in response to the activities of what he terms the anti-transgender movement that pushes "a radical agenda to deny the basic rights of trans people (...) under the cover of 'free speech.'"<ref>{{cite journal |author-last1=McLean |author-first1=Craig |title=The Growth of the Anti-Transgender Movement in the United Kingdom. The Silent Radicalization of the British Electorate |journal=International Journal of Sociology |date=2021 |volume=51 |issue=6 |pages=473–482 |doi=10.1080/00207659.2021.1939946 |s2cid=237874806 |url=http://nrl.northumbria.ac.uk/id/eprint/46370/9/The%20Growth%20of%20the%20Anti%20Transgender%20Movement%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom%20The%20Silent%20Radicalization%20of%20the%20British%20Electorate.pdf |access-date=28 June 2023 |archive-date=14 December 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211214191327/https://nrl.northumbria.ac.uk/id/eprint/46370/9/The%20Growth%20of%20the%20Anti%20Transgender%20Movement%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom%20The%20Silent%20Radicalization%20of%20the%20British%20Electorate.pdf |url-status=live }}</ref>
In Resolution 2417 (2022), the [[Council of Europe]] condemned "the highly prejudicial anti-gender, gender-critical and anti-trans narratives which reduce the fight for the equality of LGBTI people to what these movements deliberately mischaracterise as 'gender ideology' or 'LGBTI ideology'. Such narratives deny the very existence of LGBTI people, dehumanise them, and often falsely portray their rights as being in conflict with women's and children's rights, or societal and family values in general. All of these are deeply damaging to LGBTI people, while also harming women's and children's rights and social cohesion." The resolution further deplored "the extensive and often virulent attacks on the rights of LGBTI people that have been occurring for several years in, among other countries, Hungary, Poland, the Russian Federation, Turkey and the United Kingdom."<ref name=Resolution2417>{{cite web |title=Resolution 2417 (2022): Combating rising hate against LGBTI people in Europe |url=https://pace.coe.int/en/files/29712/html |date=25 January 2022 |publisher=[[Council of Europe]] |access-date=28 June 2023 |archive-date=19 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221119052750/https://pace.coe.int/en/files/29712/html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Duffy |first=Nick |date=25 January 2022 |title=Council of Europe condemns 'virulent attacks on LGBT rights' in the UK, Hungary and Poland |work=[[i (newspaper)|i]] |url=https://inews.co.uk/news/world/council-of-europe-condemns-virulent-attacks-on-lgbt-rights-uk-1423399 |access-date=30 January 2022 |archive-date=30 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220130182653/https://inews.co.uk/news/world/council-of-europe-condemns-virulent-attacks-on-lgbt-rights-uk-1423399 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Council of Europe compares UK to Russia and Poland over 'virulent attacks' on LGBT+ rights |url=https://www.thepinknews.com/2022/01/25/council-of-europe-uk-lgbt-trans-rights-russ-apoland/ |access-date=28 June 2023 |work=PinkNews |archive-date=30 May 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230530233726/https://www.thepinknews.com/2022/01/25/council-of-europe-uk-lgbt-trans-rights-russ-apoland/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
=== United States === Although gender-critical feminism originated in the United States in the 1970s, it has largely fallen out of favor among American feminists.<ref name="Burns 2019"/> Some trans-exclusionary radical-feminist organizations do remain, however, such as [[WoLF]], a trans-exclusionary radical feminist organization that operates mainly within the United States.<ref name="Burns 2019" />
=== South Korea === In 2016, the radical feminist online community [[Womad (website)|Womad]] split from the larger radical feminist online community [[Megalia]] after Megalia issued a ban on the use of certain explicit slurs against gay men and transgender people. This change in policy led to the migration of [[anti-LGBT]] members.<ref name=":0b">{{Cite news|last=Kim|first=Ashley|date=8 September 2019|title=Womad: The New Face of Feminism in Korea?|work=[[Berkeley Political Review]]|url=https://bpr.berkeley.edu/2019/09/08/womad-the-new-face-of-feminism-in-korea/|access-date=2 October 2021|archive-date=29 June 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230629035406/https://bpr.berkeley.edu/2019/09/08/womad-the-new-face-of-feminism-in-korea/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://koreaexpose.com/megalia-south-korean-feminism-marshals-the-power-of-the-internet/|title=Megalia: South Korean Feminism Marshals the Power of the Internet|journal=Korea Expose|author=Emily Singh|date=29 July 2016|access-date=7 December 2021|archive-date=29 June 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230629035405/https://koreaexpose.com/megalia-south-korean-feminism-marshals-the-power-of-the-internet/|url-status=live}}</ref>
== Scholarly analysis ==
[[Lesbian studies]] scholars Carly Thomsen and Laurie Essig note that "transness has been and is the object of deep hostility within some marginalized forms of feminism. Skepticism among earlier anti-trans feminists, such as Janice Raymond, about trans women being "real" women has morphed into J.K. Rowling's Twitter feed where she has insisted that trans women are not women. These ideas are, of course, deplorable, but they are also quite fringe within feminist studies and activism in the US."<ref name=Thomsen>{{cite journal |last1=Thomsen |first1=Carly |last2=Essig |first2=Laurie |title=Lesbian, feminist, TERF: a queer attack on feminist studies |journal=[[Journal of Lesbian Studies]] |date=2021 |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=27–44 |doi=10.1080/10894160.2021.1950270|pmid=34313195 |s2cid=236452285 }}</ref>
Claire Thurlow notes that "the initial failure of TERF-related tropes to garner public support quickly influenced the terms of 'debate', with the rhetoric employed noticeably changed. Leaving aside that the term 'gender critical feminism' is tautology, its adoption represented the beginnings of a pivot by trans-exclusionary feminists towards language which obscures their trans-exclusionary focus. Alongside a shift from TERF to gender critical, 'anti-trans' became 'pro-women' and 'trans-exclusion' became the protection of 'sex-based rights'. These rather innocuous-sounding terms have been transformed into the language of division; exemplifying dog-whistle politics whereby the phrases act as a coded message of anti-transness to those initiated, while appearing 'reasonable' to the wider population."<ref name=Thurlow/> Gender studies scholars Serena Bassi and Greta LaFleur have noted that "TERFism is typically described as an originally fringe group of Anglophone—largely American, British, and Australian—1970s cultural feminism that has grown exponentially over the past decade partially due to heightened media exposure. In the past decade or so, the shorthand "TERF" has traveled globally through online spaces."<ref name=Bassi>{{cite journal |last1=Bassi |first1=Serena |last2=LaFleur |first2=Greta |title=Introduction: TERFs, Gender-Critical Movements, and Postfascist Feminisms |journal=[[Transgender Studies Quarterly]] |date=2022 |volume=9 |issue=3 |pages=311–333 |doi=10.1215/23289252-9836008|s2cid=253052875 |doi-access=free }}</ref> Cristan Williams notes that radical feminism has historically been predominantly trans-inclusive and considers trans-exclusionary views a minority or fringe view within radical feminism.<ref name=Williams>{{cite journal |last1=Williams |first1=Cristan |title=Radical Inclusion: Recounting the Trans Inclusive History of Radical Feminism |journal=Trans Studies Quarterly |date=2016 |volume=3 |issue=1–2 |pages=254–258 |doi=10.1215/23289252-3334463|doi-access=free }}</ref> Carrera-Fernández and DePalma argued that "the increasingly belligerent popular discourses promoted by TERF groups since the 1970s [are] appropriating feminist discourses to produce arguments that contradict basic premises of feminism."<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Carrera-Fernández |first1=María Victoria |last2=DePalma |first2=Renée |title=Feminism will be trans-inclusive or it will not be: Why do two cis-hetero woman educators support transfeminism? |journal=[[The Sociological Review]] |date=2020 |volume=68 |issue=4 |pages=745–762 |doi=10.1177/0038026120934686|s2cid=221097541 }}</ref> [[Henry F. Fradella]] noted that "while much of contemporary feminist thought has moved past biological essentialism’s outdated embrace of a sex binary to embrace trans-equality, a relatively small but vocal group of self-proclaimed 'gender-critical feminists' (who are sometimes called trans-exclusionary radical feminists or 'TERFs,' for short) eschew transgender legal rights that they perceive as potentially threatening to the rights of cisgender women. Most gender-critical arguments in that regard are fallacious; they are based on myths and false narratives that misconstrue or ignore empirical data from both the natural and social sciences. Worse yet, the gender-critical position not only threatens to undermine equality under law, but also fosters narratives that contribute to the criminal victimization of transgender persons."<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fradella |first1=Henry F.|author-link=Henry F. Fradella |title=The Imperative of Rejecting 'Gender-Critical' Feminism in the Law |journal=William & Mary Journal of Race, Gender, & Social Justice |date=2023 |volume=30 |issue=2 |doi=10.2139/ssrn.4419750}}</ref>
===Relationship with the anti-gender movement=== {{Main|Anti-gender movement}} Bassi and LaFleur note that "the trans-exclusionary feminist (TERF) movement and the so-called anti-gender movement are only rarely distinguished as movements with distinct constitutions and aims."<ref name=Bassi/> Pearce et al. note that the concept of "[[gender ideology]]" "saw increasing circulation in [[TERF|trans-exclusionary radical feminist]] discourse" from around 2016.<ref name=Pearce/> Claire Thurlow noted that "despite efforts to obscure the point, gender critical feminism continues to rely on transphobic tropes, moral panics and essentialist understandings of men and women. These factors also continue to link trans-exclusionary feminism to anti-feminist reactionary politics and other 'anti-gender' movements."<ref name=Thurlow>{{cite journal |last1=Thurlow |first1=Claire |title=From TERF to gender critical: A telling genealogy? |journal=[[Sexualities (journal)|Sexualities]] |date=2022 |doi=10.1177/13634607221107827|s2cid=252662057 }}</ref>
==Legal cases== In 2019, the ''[[Maya Forstater v Centre for Global Development]]'' tribunal case was launched by [[Maya Forstater]], crowdfunding over £120,000. Earlier that year, Forstater's consulting contract for the [[Center for Global Development|Centre for Global Development]] was not renewed after she made a number of social media posts saying that men cannot change into women.<ref>{{Cite web|date=19 December 2019|title=Researcher who lost job for tweeting 'men cannot change into women' loses employment tribunal|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/maya-forstater-transgender-test-case-equalities-act-employment-tribunal-a9253211.html|access-date=30 January 2021|website=The Independent|language=en|archive-date=22 April 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220422044712/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/maya-forstater-transgender-test-case-equalities-act-employment-tribunal-a9253211.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Forstater subsequently sued the centre, alleging that she had been discriminated against because of her views.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/life/amfightingfor-therightto-saymen-cannever-bewomen//|title='I am fighting for the right to say men can never be women'|last=Gordon|first=Jane|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=23 April 2021|access-date=23 April 2021|archive-date=12 February 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220212191006/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/life/amfightingfor-therightto-saymen-cannever-bewomen/|url-status=live}}</ref> Forstater lost her initial case, with the judge ruling that her beliefs were not protected under the [[Equality Act 2010|Equality Act]] due to their absolutism. However, in April 2021, the initial judgement was reversed, with the [[Employment Appeal Tribunal]] ruling that gender-critical beliefs were protected under the Equality Act.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cross |first1=Michael |title=Appeal backs woman over 'transphobic tweets' 10 June 2021 |url=https://www.lawgazette.co.uk/law/appeal-backs-woman-over-transphobic-tweets/5108799.article |website=lawgazette |publisher=Law Society Gazette |access-date=17 June 2021 |archive-date=17 June 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210617102834/https://www.lawgazette.co.uk/law/appeal-backs-woman-over-transphobic-tweets/5108799.article |url-status=live }}</ref> A full merits hearing on Forstater's claim that she lost her employment as a result of these beliefs was heard in March 2022, and the decision, delivered in July 2022, was that Forstater had been subjected to direct discrimination and victimisation because of her gender-critical beliefs.<ref>{{cite news |title=Maya Forstater: Woman discriminated against over trans tweets, tribunal rules |work=BBC News |date=6 July 2022 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-62061929 |access-date=25 June 2023 |archive-date=12 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230312113158/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-62061929 |url-status=live }}</ref>
In October 2020, Ann Sinnott, at the time a director of the [[LGB Alliance]], initiated a legal case calling for a judicial review of the [[Equality and Human Rights Commission]]'s guidance on the [[Equality Act 2010]], crowdfunding almost £100,000 for legal fees. The Alliance believes that the specifics of the Equality Act 2010 have been "misrepresented" by some organisations.<ref>{{Cite web|title=EHRC|url=https://lgballiance.org.uk/ehrc/|access-date=10 May 2021|website=LGB Alliance|archive-date=8 August 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220808050855/http://lgballiance.org.uk/ehrc/|url-status=live}}</ref> In May 2021 the case was found by the court to be [[Void (law)|unarguable]], Justice Henshaw stating that "the claimant has shown no arguable reason to believe the Code has misled or will mislead service providers about their responsibilities under the Act."<ref>{{Cite web|date=6 May 2021|title=Judge throws out LGB Alliance founder's fight to ban trans women from women's spaces|url=https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2021/05/06/lgb-alliance-ann-sinnott-judicial-review-fails-london-high-court-equality-act/|access-date=10 May 2021|website=[[PinkNews]]|archive-date=25 November 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221125215758/https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2021/05/06/lgb-alliance-ann-sinnott-judicial-review-fails-london-high-court-equality-act/|url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Academic freedom === Conflict between gender-critical feminists and other feminists and transgender rights activists has resulted in controversies in which the principles of academic freedom have been invoked. In Canada, conflicts have erupted over these issues in public libraries in Halifax, Toronto and Vancouver.{{citation needed|date=June 2023}} Similar conflicts have erupted at university campuses.{{citation needed|date=June 2023}}
Kathleen Lowrey, who had allegedly been fired from her additional position as associate chair of undergraduate programs for the department of anthropology at the [[University of Alberta]] after displaying gender-critical posters on her office door, teaching gender-critical material in class, and showing up halfway through a student-run queer anthology event to start arguments about "the existence and validity of trans people with a trans man in the room,"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://thegatewayonline.ca/2020/06/professor-lowrey-dismayed-over-dismissal-from-admin-role/ | title=Professor Lowrey dismayed over dismissal from admin role; others feel it is a positive step | date=11 June 2020 | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=8 December 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208170803/https://thegatewayonline.ca/2020/06/professor-lowrey-dismayed-over-dismissal-from-admin-role/ | url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://edmontonjournal.com/news/local-news/u-of-a-professor-says-she-was-dismissed-over-views-that-biological-sex-trumps-transgender-identity-for-policy-decisions/ | title=U of a professor says she was dismissed over views that biological sex trumps transgender identity for policy decisions | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=8 December 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208170801/https://edmontonjournal.com/news/local-news/u-of-a-professor-says-she-was-dismissed-over-views-that-biological-sex-trumps-transgender-identity-for-policy-decisions/ | url-status=live }}</ref> published a paper in ''[[Archives of Sexual Behavior]]'' saying that she found it particularly distressing that "almost all of my most enthusiastic public attackers were feminist academic women" and that gender-critical feminists "root their analysis in the materiality of biological sex and take the oppression of women to be linked to the control of reproduction. In the present scholarly ecumene, this aligns them in some respects with scholars who are traditional and conservative, and explains why they, like conservatives, are so often in trouble with their institutions under present conditions."<ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1007/s10508-021-01950-9 | title=Trans Ideology and the New Ptolemaism in the Academy | year=2021 | last1=Lowrey | first1=Kathleen | journal=Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume=50 | issue=3 | pages=757–760 | pmid=33660161 | s2cid=232112514 | doi-access=free }}</ref>
Carolyn Sale of the Center for Free Expression at Ryerson University condemned the university's decision, saying that "the idea that in a hush behind closed doors students can bring complaints that don't have to be proven true and can do so in order to protect their "safety" should alarm us all."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://cfe.ryerson.ca/blog/2020/06/academic-freedom-and-perceptions-harm | title=Academic Freedom and Perceptions of Harm | Centre for Free Expression | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=8 December 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208170812/https://cfe.ryerson.ca/blog/2020/06/academic-freedom-and-perceptions-harm | url-status=live }}</ref>
In September 2022, Laura Favaro published an article in ''[[Times Higher Education]]'' discussing her research into the climate of the debate among academics. Noting that she had interviewed 50 feminist academics in gender studies with a range of views on the subject, Favaro stated "my discussions left me in no doubt that a culture of discrimination, silencing and fear has taken hold across universities in England, and many countries beyond."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Favaro |first=Laura |date=15 September 2022 |title=Researchers are wounded in academia's gender wars |url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/depth/researchers-are-wounded-academias-gender-wars |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220916233729/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/depth/researchers-are-wounded-academias-gender-wars |archive-date=16 September 2022 |access-date=4 October 2023 |website=Times Higher Education (THE) |language=en}}</ref> Favaro later began discrimination proceedings against [[City, University of London]], stating she had been "ostracised at her workplace and denied access to her research data" after the publication of her article.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Somerville |first=Ewan |date=15 April 2023 |title=University 'blocks' academic from her own gender wars research over 'dangerous' data |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2023/04/15/university-blocks-academic-gender-wars-research/ |access-date=4 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230508091117/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2023/04/15/university-blocks-academic-gender-wars-research/ |archive-date=8 May 2023 |issn=0307-1235}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite web |date=30 August 2023 |title=Laura Favaro: gender studies 'groupthink is forcing scholars out' |url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/laura-favaro-gender-studies-groupthink-forcing-scholars-out |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230830174319/https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/laura-favaro-gender-studies-groupthink-forcing-scholars-out |archive-date=30 August 2023 |access-date=4 October 2023 |website=Times Higher Education (THE) |language=en}}</ref>
City, University of London responded with a statement that it had a “legal obligation to protect freedom of expression that we take very seriously.” It also took its “obligations with respect to ethics and integrity very seriously” and made clear that “any personal data processed in the course of any research [should be] processed in compliance with data protection legislation.”<ref name=":8" />
=== Conflicts with other feminist and pro-equality groups === In February 2020, 28 feminist and LGBT groups in France co-signed a declaration titled ''Toutes des femmes'' denouncing trans-exclusionary feminism, saying that "questions disguised as 'legitimate concerns' quickly give way to more violent attacks" and that "it is a confusionist and conspiratorial ideological movement using the cover of feminism to disrupt real feminist fights.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.liberation.fr/debats/2020/02/26/le-debat-sur-la-place-des-femmes-trans-n-a-pas-lieu-d-etre_1779708/ | title=Le débat sur la place des femmes trans n'a pas lieu d'être | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=17 May 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210517001126/https://www.liberation.fr/debats/2020/02/26/le-debat-sur-la-place-des-femmes-trans-n-a-pas-lieu-d-etre_1779708/ | url-status=live }}</ref> The declaration has since also been signed by over 100 additional feminist, LGBT, and progressive groups.<ref name="Toutes des femmes">{{cite web | url=https://toutesdesfemmes.fr/signataires/ | title=Les signataires - Toutes des Femmes | date=25 February 2020 | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=8 December 2021 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208170603/https://toutesdesfemmes.fr/signataires/ | url-status=live }}</ref> In May 2021, over 110 women's and human rights organisations in Canada signed a statement stating that they "vehemently reject the dangerous and bigoted rhetoric and ideology espoused by Trans Exclusionary Radical 'Feminists' (TERFs)", and saying that "trans people are a driving force in our feminist movements and make incredible contributions across all facets of our society."<ref name="Canada 110">{{Cite web|url=https://www.actioncanadashr.org/news/2021-05-04-our-feminism-trans-inclusive|title=Our Feminism is Trans Inclusive. | Action Canada for Sexual Health and Rights|access-date=8 December 2021|archive-date=12 June 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210612151421/https://www.actioncanadashr.org/news/2021-05-04-our-feminism-trans-inclusive|url-status=live}}</ref>
[[Judith Butler]] said in 2020 that trans-exclusionary radical feminism is "a fringe movement that is seeking to speak in the name of the mainstream, and that our responsibility is to refuse to let that happen."<ref>{{cite news |title=Judith Butler on the culture wars, JK Rowling and living in "anti-intellectual times" |url=https://www.newstatesman.com/uncategorized/2020/09/judith-butler-culture-wars-jk-rowling-and-living-anti-intellectual-times |access-date=17 November 2021 |work=New Statesman |archive-date=17 April 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220417111403/https://www.newstatesman.com/uncategorized/2020/09/judith-butler-culture-wars-jk-rowling-and-living-anti-intellectual-times |url-status=live }}</ref>
In 2021, the [[Council of Europe]] Committee on Equality and Non-Discrimination published a report titled ''Combating rising hate against LGBTI people in Europe'', which condemned "the highly prejudicial anti-gender, gender-critical and anti-trans narratives which reduce the fight for the equality of LGBTI people to what these movements deliberately mischaracterise as '[[gender ideology]]' or '[[LGBT "ideology"|LGBTI ideology]]'" and which said there was "a direct link between heteronormativity and heterosexism, on the one hand, and the growing anti-gender and gender-critical movements."<ref name="Council of Europe 2021">{{citation |url=https://assembly.coe.int/LifeRay/EGA/Pdf/TextesProvisoires/2021/20210921-RisingHateLGBTI-EN.pdf |title=Combating rising hate against LGBTI people in Europe (Provisional version) |first=Fourat |last=Ben Chika |publisher=[[Council of Europe]] Committee on Equality and Non-Discrimination |date=21 September 2021 |access-date=8 December 2021 |archive-date=23 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210923211038/https://assembly.coe.int/LifeRay/EGA/Pdf/TextesProvisoires/2021/20210921-RisingHateLGBTI-EN.pdf |url-status=live }}</ref> The report formed the basis of Resolution 2417, adopted in January 2022.<ref name=Resolution2417/>
In late-January 2018, over 1000 Irish feminists, including several groups such as the [[University College Dublin]] Centre of Gender, Feminisms & Sexualities, signed an open letter condemning a planned meeting in Ireland on UK Gender Recognition Act reforms organised by a British group opposing the reforms.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://gcn.ie/ireland-says-no-to-terfs/ | title=Ireland Says No to TERFs | date=24 January 2018 | access-date=8 December 2021 | archive-date=24 February 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220224001108/https://gcn.ie/ireland-says-no-to-terfs/ | url-status=live }}</ref> The letter stated that "Trans people and particularly trans women are an inextricable part of our feminist community" and accused the British group of colonialism.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.irishcentral.com/news/irish-feminists-warn-away-british-terfs|title = "Stay away from Ireland," British anti-trans feminists told|date = 23 January 2018|access-date = 8 December 2021|archive-date = 1 December 2021|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20211201205946/https://www.irishcentral.com/news/irish-feminists-warn-away-british-terfs|url-status = live}}</ref>
=== Social media === The controversial Reddit community [[Controversial Reddit communities#GenderCritical|r/GenderCritical]] gathered a reputation as an anti-trans space. In June 2020, it was banned abruptly for violating new rules against "promoting hate". Members set up a similar community called Ovarit.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web |date=2023-04-28 |title=TERFs and The Donald: The Future of Reddit's Banned Groups - The Atlantic |website=[[The Atlantic]] |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2020/12/reddit-ovarit-the-donald/617320/ |access-date=2023-10-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230428050258/https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2020/12/reddit-ovarit-the-donald/617320/ |archive-date=28 April 2023 }}</ref>
=== Allegations of misinformation tactics === T.J. Billard in article on "TERF strategies" has stated that "misinformation—or, more specifically, disinformation—about trans topics has become the defining feature of public discourse on transgender rights."<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal |last=Billard |first=Thomas J |date=2023-04-03 |title="Gender-Critical" Discourse as Disinformation: Unpacking TERF Strategies of Political Communication |url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/07491409.2023.2193545 |journal=Women's Studies in Communication |language=en |volume=46 |issue=2 |pages=235–243 |doi=10.1080/07491409.2023.2193545 |s2cid=258464300 |issn=0749-1409}}</ref> Cilia Williams et al. noted in an article on gender critical feminist discourse in Spain that "anti-trans narratives online [...] use attacks, misinformation, and self-defence as a communication strategy, rather than debate or dialogue."<ref name=":2">{{Citation |last=Tortajada |first=Cilia Willem , R. Lucas Platero , Iolanda |title=Trans-exclusionary Discourses on Social Media in Spain |date=2022 |work=Identities and Intimacies on Social Media |pages=185–200 |publisher=Routledge |doi=10.4324/9781003250982-15 |isbn=978-1-003-25098-2|doi-access=free }}</ref> Alyosxa Tudor has written that "strategic disinformation as [an] accelerator" has been used to push forward "hateful and anti-democratic agendas."<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal |last=Tudor |first=Alyosxa |date=May 2023 |title=The anti-feminism of anti-trans feminism |journal=European Journal of Women's Studies |language=en |volume=30 |issue=2 |pages=290–302 |doi=10.1177/13505068231164217 |issn=1350-5068|doi-access=free }}</ref> These accusations have been made in an environment where disinformation on social media has become a significant area of concern for many scholars in political science, according to a literature review.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Pérez-Escolar |first1=Marta |last2=Lilleker |first2=Darren |last3=Tapia-Frade |first3=Alejandro |date=2023-04-28 |title=A Systematic Literature Review of the Phenomenon of Disinformation and Misinformation |url=https://www.cogitatiopress.com/mediaandcommunication/article/view/6453 |journal=Media and Communication |language=en |volume=11 |issue=2 |pages=76–87 |doi=10.17645/mac.v11i2.6453 |issn=2183-2439 |doi-access=free }}</ref>
